verses.text: If a man takes a wife and marries her, but she does not find favor in his eyes because he has found something indecent about her, and he writes her a certificate of divorce, puts it in her hand, and sends her out of his house,
verses.comment: This law sets the procedure for divorce under the Mosaic Covenant. Jesus references this command in Matthew 19:7-9, clarifying that it was permitted because of the hardness of heart but was not God's original intention.

verses.text: and she leaves his house and goes and becomes the wife of another man,
verses.comment: Remarriage of the divorced woman is considered here. Jeremiah 3:1 draws a spiritual parallel, warning Israel against unfaithfulness to God.

verses.text: and the second husband dislikes her and writes her a certificate of divorce, puts it in her hand, and sends her out of his house, or if the second husband who took her as wife dies,
verses.comment: The law considers not only divorce but also the scenario where the second husband dies, indicating the importance of regulated marriage practices.

verses.text: then her former husband who sent her away may not take her again to be his wife after she has been defiled, for that is an abomination before the LORD. And you shall not bring sin upon the land that the LORD your God is giving you as an inheritance.
verses.comment: This law prohibits remarriage to the former husband, which protected against casual divorce and upheld the sanctity of marriage. This foreshadows the New Testament's higher call to indissoluble union (see Matt. 19:6, Mark 10:9).

verses.text: When a man has taken a new wife, he shall not go out with the army or be charged with any business; he shall be free at home for one year to bring happiness to the wife he has taken.
verses.comment: This provision prioritizes the establishment of a strong family foundation, showing the vital importance of marital unity in God's plan (see also Deut. 20:7 for related exemptions).

verses.text: No one shall take a mill or an upper millstone as a pledge, for he would be taking a life in pledge.
verses.comment: Pledging essential items for survival is forbidden, emphasizing justice and compassion toward the poor—key themes fulfilled in Christ’s ministry to the needy and marginalized.

verses.text: If anyone is found kidnapping one of his Israelite brothers, treating him as a slave or selling him, then that kidnapper shall die. So you shall purge the evil from among you.
verses.comment: Kidnapping and enslaving a fellow Israelite was a capital crime. The seriousness reflects the sanctity and dignity of every individual, foundational for later Christian teachings on human dignity.

verses.text: Be careful in a case of leprous disease, to follow carefully all that the Levitical priests shall direct you. As I have commanded them, so you shall be careful to do.
verses.comment: The Levitical priests mediate God’s instructions regarding ritual purity—hinting at a divinely-instituted priesthood acting as a link between God and His people (see also Matt. 8:4 where Jesus acknowledges this authority).

verses.text: Remember what the LORD your God did to Miriam on the way as you came out of Egypt.
verses.comment: A warning not to disregard the seriousness of ritual impurity or oppose God-appointed leaders. This historical example recalls God's just discipline but also His mercy.

verses.text: When you make your neighbor a loan of any kind, you shall not go into his house to take his pledge.
verses.comment: Respect for personal dignity in matters of debt is commanded. Justice is to be rooted in mercy and respect for one's neighbor.

verses.text: You shall stand outside, and the man to whom you make the loan shall bring out the pledge to you.
verses.comment: Further safeguards to protect the dignity of debtors and prevent exploitation are consistently demanded.

verses.text: If he is a poor man, you shall not sleep with his pledge.
verses.comment: Holding a poor man's pledge overnight (such as a cloak) would deprive him of basic necessities. Divine mercy guides legal obligations toward charity.

verses.text: You shall restore to him the pledge as the sun sets, so that he may sleep in his cloak and bless you. And it shall be righteousness for you before the LORD your God.
verses.comment: Acts of charity are seen as righteousness before God—a theme later echoed in both Old Testament and New Testament teachings (see Matt. 25:40).

verses.text: You shall not oppress a hired worker who is poor and needy, whether he is one of your brothers or a sojourner who is in your land within your gates.
verses.comment: Just and compassionate treatment of laborers is commanded—fulfilled in Christ’s own call for treating others as we would be treated (see Jas. 5:4).

verses.text: You shall give him his wages on the same day, before the sun sets (for he is poor and counts on it), so that he does not cry out against you to the LORD, and you become guilty of sin.
verses.comment: Delayed payment is treated as sin. Immediate care for workers' needs reflects a principle of social justice rooted in divine law.

verses.text: Fathers shall not be put to death for their children, nor shall children be put to death for their fathers. Each person shall be put to death for his own sin.
verses.comment: A person is responsible for his own sins. This individual moral accountability is developed further by the prophets (Ezek. 18:20), and in the offer of forgiveness through Christ (Acts 2:38).

verses.text: You shall not pervert the justice due to the sojourner or to the fatherless, nor take a widow's garment as a pledge.
verses.comment: Justice for the vulnerable—sojourners, orphans, widows—is demanded repeatedly. God’s people are called to mercy, which fully comes to light in the Gospel (Luke 4:18; Jas. 1:27).

verses.text: But you shall remember that you were a slave in Egypt, and the LORD your God redeemed you from there; therefore I command you to do this.
verses.comment: God grounds His law in salvation history: Israel is to show mercy because God redeemed them. This is echoed spiritually in the New Covenant, where Christ redeems believers (Eph. 1:7).

verses.text: When you reap your harvest in your field and forget a sheaf in the field, you shall not go back to get it. It shall be for the sojourner, the fatherless, and the widow, so that the LORD your God may bless you in all the work of your hands.
verses.comment: Provision for the poor is built into the agricultural laws, foreshadowing the charity that will be fully realized in the community of believers (Acts 4:34-35).

verses.text: When you beat your olive trees, you shall not go over the boughs again. It shall be for the sojourner, the fatherless, and the widow.
verses.comment: A repeated command to leave some provision for the marginalized; this embodies God’s justice and mercy.

verses.text: When you gather the grapes of your vineyard, you shall not glean it afterward. It shall be for the sojourner, the fatherless, and the widow.
verses.comment: Every aspect of daily life, even gathering food, is an opportunity to practice justice and charity. Believers are called to this same spirit of generosity in Christ.

verses.text: You shall remember that you were a slave in the land of Egypt; therefore I command you to do this.
verses.comment: God's people are to act with compassion because of God's salvation—reminding us that grace received is meant to be shared, culminating in the new commandment of love given by Jesus (John 13:34-35).
